sayings.portuguese: Quem não tem cão, caça com gato.
sayings.pronunciation: keng nowng teng KOWNG, KAH-suh kong GAH-too
sayings.literal: Who doesn't have a dog, hunts with a cat.
sayings.meaning: Make do with what you have. Work with whatever resources are available.
sayings.usage: When someone finds a creative solution because the ideal option isn't available.
sayings.example: Não temos impressora, mas podemos fotografar o documento. Quem não tem cão, caça com gato.
sayings.exampleTranslation: We don't have a printer, but we can photograph the document. You make do with what you have.

sayings.portuguese: Água mole em pedra dura, tanto bate até que fura.
sayings.pronunciation: AH-gwuh MOL eng PEH-druh DOO-ruh, TAN-too BAH-tuh ah-TEH kuh FOO-ruh
sayings.literal: Soft water on hard stone, hits so much until it pierces.
sayings.meaning: Persistence pays off. Constant effort achieves results over time.
sayings.usage: When encouraging someone not to give up on a long-term goal.

sayings.portuguese: Devagarinho se vai ao longe.
sayings.pronunciation: deh-vuh-guh-REE-nyoo suh vai ow LONZH
sayings.literal: Slowly, one goes far.
sayings.meaning: Slow and steady wins the race. Take your time and you'll get there.
sayings.usage: When someone is rushing and you want to remind them that patience leads to better results.

sayings.portuguese: Mais vale tarde do que nunca.
sayings.pronunciation: maish VAL TARD doo kuh NOON-kuh
sayings.literal: Better late than never.
sayings.meaning: It's better to do something late than not at all.
sayings.usage: When someone finally does something they've been putting off.

sayings.portuguese: Quem tudo quer, tudo perde.
sayings.pronunciation: keng TOO-doo kehr, TOO-doo PEHRD
sayings.literal: Who wants everything, loses everything.
sayings.meaning: Being too greedy leads to losing it all.
sayings.usage: When someone is overextending themselves or being too ambitious at once.

sayings.portuguese: Não há bem que sempre dure, nem mal que nunca se cure.
sayings.pronunciation: nowng ah beng kuh SEMP-ruh DOOR, neng mal kuh NOON-kuh suh KOOR
sayings.literal: There's no good that always lasts, nor bad that never heals.
sayings.meaning: Nothing lasts forever — neither good times nor bad.
sayings.usage: When comforting someone going through a tough time.

sayings.portuguese: A esperança é a última a morrer.
sayings.pronunciation: uh shpuh-RAN-suh eh uh OOL-tee-muh uh moo-RREHR
sayings.literal: Hope is the last to die.
sayings.meaning: Never give up hope. Hope persists even in the darkest times.
sayings.usage: When things look bleak but there's still a chance.

sayings.portuguese: Cada macaco no seu galho.
sayings.pronunciation: KAH-duh muh-KAH-koo noo seh-oo GAH-lyoo
sayings.literal: Each monkey on its own branch.
sayings.meaning: Mind your own business. Everyone should stick to what they know.
sayings.usage: When someone is meddling in affairs that don't concern them.

sayings.portuguese: Em terra de cegos, quem tem um olho é rei.
sayings.pronunciation: eng TEH-rruh duh SEH-goosh, keng teng oom OH-lyoo eh rray
sayings.literal: In the land of the blind, the one-eyed man is king.
sayings.meaning: Among people with no skill, even a little knowledge makes you stand out.
sayings.usage: When someone with basic skills excels because everyone else knows even less.

sayings.portuguese: Quem com ferros mata, com ferros morre.
sayings.pronunciation: keng kong FEH-rroosh MAH-tuh, kong FEH-rroosh MOH-rruh
sayings.literal: Who kills with iron, dies by iron.
sayings.meaning: What goes around comes around. You reap what you sow.
sayings.usage: When someone faces consequences for their own bad actions.

sayings.portuguese: De grão em grão, enche a galinha o papo.
sayings.pronunciation: duh growng eng growng, EN-shuh uh guh-LEE-nyuh oo PAH-poo
sayings.literal: Grain by grain, the hen fills her crop.
sayings.meaning: Little by little, small efforts add up to big results.
sayings.usage: When saving money or making slow but steady progress.

sayings.portuguese: Gato escaldado de água fria tem medo.
sayings.pronunciation: GAH-too shkal-DAH-doo duh AH-gwuh FREE-uh teng MEH-doo
sayings.literal: A scalded cat is afraid of cold water.
sayings.meaning: Once burned, twice shy. Bad experiences make you cautious.
sayings.usage: When someone is overly cautious because of a past bad experience.

sayings.portuguese: A bom entendedor, meia palavra basta.
sayings.pronunciation: uh bong en-ten-duh-DOHR, MAY-uh puh-LAH-vruh BASH-tuh
sayings.literal: To a good understander, half a word is enough.
sayings.meaning: A word to the wise is sufficient. Smart people catch on quickly.
sayings.usage: When hinting at something without saying it directly.

sayings.portuguese: Quem vai ao mar, avia-se em terra.
sayings.pronunciation: keng vai ow MAR, uh-VEE-uh-suh eng TEH-rruh
sayings.literal: Who goes to sea, prepares on land.
sayings.meaning: Prepare properly before starting something. Plan ahead.
sayings.usage: When reminding someone to get ready before a trip or project.

sayings.portuguese: Comer e coçar, é só começar.
sayings.pronunciation: koo-MEHR ee koo-SAR, eh soh koo-muh-SAR
sayings.literal: Eating and scratching, you just have to start.
sayings.meaning: The hardest part is getting started. Once you begin, it gets easier.
sayings.usage: When someone is procrastinating — just take the first step.

sayings.portuguese: Depois da tempestade vem a bonança.
sayings.pronunciation: duh-POYSH duh tem-push-TAH-duh veng uh boo-NAN-suh
sayings.literal: After the storm comes the calm.
sayings.meaning: Bad times are followed by good times. Things will get better.
sayings.usage: When comforting someone during a difficult period.

sayings.portuguese: Nem tudo o que reluz é ouro.
sayings.pronunciation: neng TOO-doo oo kuh rruh-LOOZ eh OH-roo
sayings.literal: Not everything that shines is gold.
sayings.meaning: Appearances can be deceiving. Don't judge by the surface.
sayings.usage: When something looks great on the outside but might not be as good as it seems.

sayings.portuguese: Não se apanham trutas a braços enxutos.
sayings.pronunciation: nowng suh uh-PAH-nyung TROO-tush uh BRAH-soosh en-SHOO-toosh
sayings.literal: You don't catch trout with dry arms.
sayings.meaning: You have to get your hands dirty to achieve results. No effort, no reward.
sayings.usage: When someone wants results without putting in the work.

sayings.portuguese: Quem não tem dinheiro não tem vícios.
sayings.pronunciation: keng nowng teng dee-NYAY-roo nowng teng VEE-see-oosh
sayings.literal: Who has no money has no vices.
sayings.meaning: Being broke keeps you out of trouble. Poverty limits temptation.
sayings.usage: Humorous — when you can't afford something indulgent.

sayings.portuguese: O barato sai caro.
sayings.pronunciation: oo buh-RAH-too sai KAH-roo
sayings.literal: The cheap comes out expensive.
sayings.meaning: You get what you pay for. Buying cheap often costs more in the long run.
sayings.usage: When a budget purchase breaks or fails quickly.

sayings.portuguese: Quem não arrisca, não petisca.
sayings.pronunciation: keng nowng uh-RREE-shuh, nowng puh-TEESH-kuh
sayings.literal: Who doesn't risk, doesn't snack.
sayings.meaning: Nothing ventured, nothing gained. You have to take risks to get rewards.
sayings.usage: When encouraging someone to take a chance.

sayings.portuguese: Deus ajuda quem se ajuda.
sayings.pronunciation: DEH-oosh uh-ZHOO-duh keng suh uh-ZHOO-duh
sayings.literal: God helps those who help themselves.
sayings.meaning: Don't wait for luck — take action and work for what you want.
sayings.usage: When someone is waiting for things to magically improve without effort.

sayings.portuguese: Isto é trabalho de inglês.
sayings.pronunciation: EESH-too eh truh-BAH-lyoo duh een-GLESH
sayings.literal: This is English work.
sayings.meaning: This is shoddy or unreliable work. (Historical reference to broken treaties.)
sayings.usage: When commenting on poor quality work — humorous and culturally specific.

sayings.portuguese: Longe da vista, longe do coração.
sayings.pronunciation: LONZH duh VEESH-tuh, LONZH doo koo-ruh-SOWNG
sayings.literal: Far from sight, far from the heart.
sayings.meaning: Out of sight, out of mind. Distance weakens relationships.
sayings.usage: When someone drifts apart from friends or family after moving away.

sayings.portuguese: Diz-me com quem andas, dir-te-ei quem és.
sayings.pronunciation: deezh-muh kong keng AN-dush, deer-tuh-AY keng ehsh
sayings.literal: Tell me who you walk with, I'll tell you who you are.
sayings.meaning: You're known by the company you keep.
sayings.usage: When commenting on someone's choice of friends or associates.

sayings.portuguese: Quem cala, consente.
sayings.pronunciation: keng KAH-luh, kon-SEN-tuh
sayings.literal: Who is silent, consents.
sayings.meaning: Silence means agreement. If you don't speak up, you're accepting the situation.
sayings.usage: When someone should voice their objection but stays quiet.

sayings.portuguese: Amigos, amigos, negócios à parte.
sayings.pronunciation: uh-MEE-goosh, uh-MEE-goosh, nuh-GOH-see-oosh ah PART
sayings.literal: Friends, friends, business aside.
sayings.meaning: Don't mix friendship and business. Keep personal and professional separate.
sayings.usage: When setting boundaries about money or work with friends.

sayings.portuguese: Quem o feio ama, bonito lhe parece.
sayings.pronunciation: keng oo FAY-oo AH-muh, boo-NEE-too lyuh puh-REH-suh
sayings.literal: Who loves the ugly, finds them beautiful.
sayings.meaning: Love is blind. When you love someone, you see beauty in them.
sayings.usage: When commenting on an unlikely couple or someone's biased view of a loved one.

sayings.portuguese: Entre marido e mulher, ninguém mete a colher.
sayings.pronunciation: EN-truh muh-REE-doo ee moo-LYEHR, neen-GENG MEH-tuh uh koo-LYEHR
sayings.literal: Between husband and wife, nobody puts a spoon.
sayings.meaning: Don't interfere in a couple's affairs.
sayings.usage: When someone tries to get involved in a couple's argument.

sayings.portuguese: Cão que ladra não morde.
sayings.pronunciation: kowng kuh LAH-druh nowng MOHRD
sayings.literal: A dog that barks doesn't bite.
sayings.meaning: People who make the most noise are often the least dangerous.
sayings.usage: When someone makes empty threats.

sayings.portuguese: Quem semeia ventos, colhe tempestades.
sayings.pronunciation: keng suh-MAY-uh VEN-toosh, KOH-lyuh tem-push-TAH-dush
sayings.literal: Who sows winds, harvests storms.
sayings.meaning: If you cause trouble, expect bigger trouble in return.
sayings.usage: When someone's bad behaviour leads to serious consequences.

sayings.portuguese: Filho de peixe sabe nadar.
sayings.pronunciation: FEE-lyoo duh PAY-shuh SAH-buh nuh-DAR
sayings.literal: Son of a fish knows how to swim.
sayings.meaning: Like father, like son. Children inherit their parents' traits.
sayings.usage: When a child shows a talent or behaviour similar to their parents.

sayings.portuguese: A mentira tem perna curta.
sayings.pronunciation: uh men-TEE-ruh teng PEHR-nuh KOOR-tuh
sayings.literal: The lie has a short leg.
sayings.meaning: Lies don't get very far. The truth always comes out.
sayings.usage: When someone gets caught lying.

sayings.portuguese: Quem não deve, não teme.
sayings.pronunciation: keng nowng DEH-vuh, nowng TEH-muh
sayings.literal: Who doesn't owe, doesn't fear.
sayings.meaning: A clear conscience fears nothing. If you've done nothing wrong, you have nothing to worry about.
sayings.usage: When someone is anxious about being investigated or questioned but has nothing to hide.

sayings.portuguese: Em boca fechada não entram moscas.
sayings.pronunciation: eng BOH-kuh fuh-SHAH-duh nowng EN-trang MOSH-kush
sayings.literal: In a closed mouth, flies don't enter.
sayings.meaning: Silence is golden. It's better to keep quiet than to say something stupid.
sayings.usage: When advising someone to not speak about something.

sayings.portuguese: Há mar e mar, há ir e voltar.
sayings.pronunciation: ah MAR ee MAR, ah eer ee vol-TAR
sayings.literal: There's sea and sea, there's going and coming back.
sayings.meaning: Be careful — things aren't always as simple as they seem. Respect the risk.
sayings.usage: Originally about sea safety, now used for any situation where caution is needed.

sayings.portuguese: Casa onde não há pão, todos ralham e ninguém tem razão.
sayings.pronunciation: KAH-zuh OND nowng ah POWNG, TOH-doosh RAH-lyung ee neen-GENG teng ruh-ZOWNG
sayings.literal: House where there's no bread, everyone argues and nobody is right.
sayings.meaning: Poverty and scarcity cause conflict. People fight when basic needs aren't met.
sayings.usage: When a stressful environment (work, home) is causing unnecessary arguments.

sayings.portuguese: Santos da casa não fazem milagres.
sayings.pronunciation: SAN-toosh duh KAH-zuh nowng FAH-zeng mee-LAH-grush
sayings.literal: Saints of the house don't perform miracles.
sayings.meaning: Familiarity breeds contempt. People don't value what's close to them.
sayings.usage: When someone's expertise is ignored at home/work but valued by outsiders.

sayings.portuguese: Anda cá e vai lá.
sayings.pronunciation: AN-duh KAH ee vai LAH
sayings.literal: Come here and go there.
sayings.meaning: Being sent back and forth. Getting the runaround.
sayings.usage: When dealing with bureaucracy or being bounced between departments.

sayings.portuguese: Para bom bebedor, meia garrafa basta.
sayings.pronunciation: PAH-ruh bong buh-buh-DOHR, MAY-uh guh-RRAH-fuh BASH-tuh
sayings.literal: For a good drinker, half a bottle is enough.
sayings.meaning: A connoisseur doesn't need excess. Quality over quantity.
sayings.usage: Humorous — when splitting wine or drinks, or appreciating something in moderation.

sayings.portuguese: Quem conta um conto, acrescenta um ponto.
sayings.pronunciation: keng KON-tuh oom KON-too, uh-kruh-SEN-tuh oom PON-too
sayings.literal: Who tells a tale, adds a stitch.
sayings.meaning: Stories get exaggerated as they're retold. Like a game of telephone.
sayings.usage: When gossip or a story has clearly been embellished.

sayings.portuguese: Não dou o braço a torcer.
sayings.pronunciation: nowng doh oo BRAH-soo uh tor-SEHR
sayings.literal: I don't give my arm to be twisted.
sayings.meaning: I won't give in. I stand by my position.
sayings.usage: When someone stubbornly refuses to change their mind (can be positive or negative).

sayings.portuguese: Meter os pés pelas mãos.
sayings.pronunciation: muh-TEHR oosh pehsh PEH-lush mowngsh
sayings.literal: Put the feet through the hands.
sayings.meaning: To mess things up completely. To make a total blunder.
sayings.usage: When someone makes a confusing or clumsy mistake.

sayings.portuguese: Vai pagar as favas!
sayings.pronunciation: vai puh-GAR ush FAH-vush
sayings.literal: Go pay for the broad beans!
sayings.meaning: Get lost! Go away! (Mild, humorous way to dismiss someone.)
sayings.usage: Casual/humorous dismissal — not aggressive, more playful.

sayings.portuguese: Estar com os azeites.
sayings.pronunciation: shtar kong oosh uh-ZAY-tush
sayings.literal: To be with the olive oils.
sayings.meaning: To be in a bad mood. To be grumpy or irritable.
sayings.usage: When someone is being moody for no apparent reason.
